abstract: General Electric, which lost its AAA rating Thursday, had maintained a high overall rating until now because of the steady cash thrown off by the industrial side of its business.
snippet: General Electric, which lost its AAA rating Thursday, had maintained a high overall rating until now because of the steady cash thrown off by the industrial side of its business.
lead_paragraph: General Electric finally lost its AAA rating. This shouldn’t affect the company’s financing costs, since the markets have ignored the rating for some time. But the conglomerate’s top rating was a big reason for keeping its industrial and financial arms together. The strength of the industrial business theoretically allowed the financial arm to raise debt cheaply, allowing it to thrive. The downgrade guts this rationale.

byline.original: By Lauren Silva Laughlin and Jeff Segal
